message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The baby has tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, and overriding aorta. Option A is incorrect because it includes an overriding aorta instead of an overriding pulmonary artery. Option B is incorrect because it includes pulmonary regurgitation instead of pulmonary stenosis. Option C is incorrect because it includes an atrial septal defect instead of a ventricular septal defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boot-shaped heart seen on the X-ray is a classic sign of Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, and overriding aorta. Option (A) has a overriding aorta but not right ventricular hypertrophy. Option (B) has pulmonary regurgitation instead of pulmonary stenosis. Option (C) has overriding pulmonary artery instead of overriding aorta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a boot-shaped heart and anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum is characteristic of tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, and overriding aorta. Answer choice A includes left ventricular hypertrophy, which is not a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot. Answer choice B includes pulmonary regurgitation, which can occur in some cases of tetralogy of Fallot, but is not one of the four characteristic features. Answer choice C includes atrial septal defect, which is not a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot.

Option (A) has overriding aorta but the wrong type of ventricular hypertrophy, option (B) has pulmonary regurgitation instead of pulmonary stenosis, and option (C) has overriding pulmonary artery instead of overriding aorta.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum causes Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, and overriding aorta. Option (A) is incorrect because there is no overriding aorta. Options (B) and (C) are incorrect because there is no pulmonary regurgitation or atrial septal defect.
